thread.title: De Blasio Expected to Endorse Clinton ‘Very Soon’
thread.title_full: De Blasio Expected to Endorse Clinton ‘Very Soon’

author: Ryan Haas
title: De Blasio Expected to Endorse Clinton ‘Very Soon’
text:
Share 
It’s a matter of when, not if. 
That’s, at least, what it appears to be a question of surrounding Mayor Bill de Blasio’s endorsement announcement of Hillary Clinton. 
A Clinton campaign source told POLITICO New York that de Blasio’s team has discussed with the former senator’s camp about the possibility of an endorsement, and a person familiar with de Blasio’s thinking said the mayor was expected to endorse her “very soon and before the forum” he’s holding in Iowa City on Dec. 6. 
De Blasio managed Clinton’s campaign for Senate in 2000, and was sworn in by former president Bill Clinton. But the New York City mayor has oddly held off endorsing his former boss’s presidential bid — something the entire New York Democratic establishment has done. 
The mayor, who has sought to position himself as a progressive on the national stage, claimed he “wanted to see more details from the candidates about their intentions before he made a final decision.” 
“I think like a lot of people in this country, I want to see a vision,” said de Blasio in April, on the same day Clinton formally announced her run for the White House. “And again that would be true of candidates on all levels.” 
Mayor de Blasio has deep roots to the Clinton world, having worked for Bill Clinton at the federal department of housing and urban development under current Gov. Andrew Cuomo. 
An organization, founded by de Blasio, is set to host a presidential forum on income inequality in Iowa City in December, sending out a multitude of invitations to all the major Democratic and Republican candidates. But the response was tepid, with Bernie Sanders and Clinton remaining on the fence as to whether they’ll attend de Blasio’s forum. 
On Monday, Clinton’s campaign released a list comprising of more than 100 New York leaders who will make up her state leadership council. That list includes every Democratic House member from New York and both U.S. senators, all of the statewide leaders and every New York City-wide leader with the exception of de Blasio. Print Friendly 10/26/2015 4:58 PM by Ryan Haas
